entry.title: SAP BTP Global Account audit logs using SAP BTP Auditlog service, SAP Build Apps and SAP Ai Core
entry.content:
Let’s assume you are responsible for your company’s global account on the SAP BTP and would like to know what happens in the global account itself and in the subaccounts, right? I’m going to show you one of the practical and (in my opinion) giving some fun solutions.

Let’s start with the BTP basics. The platform gathers and stores crucial information about what happened in form of audit logs. These logs are being gathered and stored on two levels: global account level and subaccount level. Access to the audit logs on the subaccount level is simple – you can use the SAP BTP service called Audit Log Viewer. It is free of charge as per date of writing. But situation on the global account level is different – there is no way to run any service directly in the global account, so you can’t use Audit Log Viewer here. But your logs are still there – you just need to expose them via REST API and then access them – again via the REST API.

 

Exposing the global account logs.

Here we need one of the SAP BTP services, the SAP AuditLog service. Keep in mind that there are two versions of this service: free and paid. The free version is enough if standard log retention period of 90 days is enough. And this is the only option in case of the global account audit logs. In case of a subaccount though,  you can extend the retention time over 90 days, but you need the paid, premium version in this case. You also need the premium version if you want to store logs generated by your own applications, running in the SAP BTP subaccount. More information here: Retention of Audit Data written from SAP BTP Applications and Services and here: Retention of Audit Data written from Customer’s BTP Applications

To run any SAP BTP service, first we need a subaccount for this service (or services). I strongly recommend creating one subaccount, dedicated just to the platform management. I would call it “technical” subaccount. This “technical” subaccount would serve purely for SAP BTP management and monitoring purposes – no business-related solutions should be placed here.

First thing to do after subaccount creation should be establishing trust with your IAS (if you use IAS, what I strongly recommend) and assigning “Subaccount Administrator” role collection to the appropriate people.

Then, on the global account level, assign the Auditlog Management Service, “central” plan to the “technical” subaccount. Please note it must be “central” plan and not any other.

Go to your “technical” subaccount and find the “Service Marketplace”. In the Service Marketplace, find the Auditlog service and under three dots select “Create”. Now it is important to create instance of this service with “central” plan – this is the only plan allowing access to the global account audit logs.

When service instance is created, click the arrow on the right-hand end of the instance line, find section called “Service Keys” and press “Create”. The only information you need to provide in this step is how you want to name the new service key – nothing more.

When service key is generated, you can access the Auditlog Management service via the REST API – right now click the tree dots on the right-hand end of the service key line and select “download”. This will give you the Auditlog service’s service key in form of “txt” file, but in fact the internal structure of this file is JSON, so if you change the file extension from “txt” to “json”, you will see the service key JSON-formatted in any tool supporting this format. You will need this file in a moment. But before you can access the logs, you need to assign correct privileges to you and/or anybody else who should have access to the audit logs of the global account. The Auditlog Management service is unique in the way that it doesn’t provide ready to use role collection – instead it provides just a role “Audilog_Auditor”. You must add this role to one of the existing role collections or create your own role collection, add this role and assign this new role collection to the appropriate people – or preferably, map them to the IAS groups of users.

Destination definition.

Regardless of whether you use a Pro-Code or No-Code approach, the SAP BTP Destination will be very helpful—especially for authentication. Therefore, we’ll begin by defining the SAP BTP Destination that points to the SAP Auditlog service. Go to the SAP BTP Cockpit, to the subaccount where your application development environment is running. If you have no access to this subaccount or have no “Subaccount Administrator” nor at least “Destination Administrator” rights for this subaccount, you need to find someone who has such privileges, and this parson must perform the next action: define SAP BTP destination to the Auditlog service.

Creating the destination is a standard and easy process – you just need to provide information found in the Auditlog service’s service key you already downloaded, like service address, authentication type, authentication address, client id and client credentials. But for the destination to work properly in SAP Build Apps, we need also to define some “Additional Properties”.

The data for SAP BTP Destination:

  • Name: “Central_Audit_Log_Service” – it is up to you how you name it, but the name should be meaningful, and you should be able to tell what the purpose of this destination is just based on its name even after a year or so.
  • Type: HTTP
  • Proxy Type: Internet
  • URL: open the downloaded service key file and find the “url:” line. Note: this is the very first “url” you can see in the file. Copy the full address with “http://”, but without the quotation marks. It should look like this:
    https://auditlog-management.xxxx.xxxx.xxxx.ondemand.com
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • Client ID: copy the content of the “clientid” line you can find in the “uaa” section of the service key – again without the quotation marks
  • Client Secret: copy the content of the “clientsecret” line you can find in the “uaa” section of the service key – again without the quotation marks
  • Token Service URL: here you have to combine the content of the “url” line you can find in the “uaa” section – again without the quotation marks – with the following: “/oauth/token”.
    Note 1: do NOT use the first “url” from the service key file here! In this field you must use the “url” you find INSIDE the “uaa” section.
    Note 2: the full Token Service address should look like this: https://xxxxx.xxxxxx.xxxx.xxxxxxx.com/oauth/token
  • Token Service URL Type: Dedicated

Additional Properties:

The absolute minimum is the following:

  • BuildApps.Enabled = true
  • BuildApps.ApiType = rest

On top, I would suggest adding the following, to be able to use the same destination in the future in other SAP Build tools and for other purposes, like automation, for instance:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true
  • MobileEnabled = true

Save the destination and check the connection – it should give response like this:

 

 

Building the application.

I recommend using SAP Build Apps for this purpose as it is the simples, fastest and most funny way to achieve our goal.

I assume here, that you already have access to SAP Build Apps or at least you know how to get it. If not, please ask your SAP Account Executive or SAP partner.

Create a new SAP Build Apps project as usual. Ensure that the SAP BTP Authentication is enabled. The application pages structure is up to you – for example you could put the list of log records immediately on the starting page or if you prefer, you can make starting page just for information, describing application purpose and put here a button to open a new page, the one actually showing the list of log records – you can do it your own way. Importantly, you should create a page that displays a list of records. You can use any existing “List” artefact, but I prefer to do it my own way, using a row, which “repeats” with output from the Auditlog service call.

 

Task 1: Getting access to the Auditlog data.

Thanks to the destination we prepared in the previous step, it will be easy task:

  1. Go to the “Integrations” tab
  2. In the “Integrations” section press the blue button “ADD INTEGRATION” – new page will open
  3. In the section “SAP Systems”, press the “BTP DESTINATIONS” button
  4. You should see the “REST API Endpoints” section and your SAP BTP destination to the Auditlog service you created during the preparation phase (“Central_Audit_Log_Sertvice” in my case) – select it
  5. Click “INSTALL INTEGRATION” in the top right corner of the screen
    This would be enough to send requests to the Auditlog service via the “HTTP Destination Request” function block and get answers, but you need a bit more: you need a data structure, identical with the structure of the answer, to repeat the list rows with.
  6. Press the “Add REST API Data Entity” button – an “Add REST API Data Entity” form will appear.
  7. Fill the form this way:
    1. Name: records
    2. Autogenerate configuration: selected
    3. Entity path within the API: /auditlog/v2/auditlogrecords
    4. Enable Capabilities: select only “list” – no other capability can be used in case of the Auditlog service
  8. Press the “Add” button
    After a few seconds you should see your “records” entity with auto-generated 11 fields. These fields were automatically read from the service thanks to the SAP BTP Destination you defined during the preparation phase.
  9. Select the “list” capability and press the “Run Test” button. If everything was done correctly so far, you should get in a few seconds the “Status: OK (200)” response above the black window and list of records inside the black window. If this is the case, you can now start shaping the UI of your app. Otherwise you need to check all the previous steps in search of mistake.

Now have a look at the list of records, visible in the black window. You can see here the structure of the answer from the Auditlog service. It is a list of objects. Object has 11 properties – the same as auto generated fields in the “records” entity. But there is a difference: the last field of the “records” entity named “message” is of “Text” type, while in the actual response it is an object with several properties. In case of a simple application, just showing logs, you should leave it as it is, but note that there is a room for further improvements of your app in the future. Leaving it as it is, you can display the “message” object as plain text, but with some work it is possible to get direct access to each property inside the “message” object in the API response. But this is outside of the scope of this article.

 

Task 2: The start page.

I recommend here creating three pages:

  • Star page
  • The log listing page
  • The record details page

Creating an app, you get one page immediately – it is your start page, so you just need to create next two pages and name them in a meaningful way, something like “List of records” and “Record details”.

So, we have:

  • “Home Page” – it is our start page
  • “List of records” – it is the page where we will see list of records and will select one of them for detailed view
  • “Record details” – it is the page where we will display all the record’s details and eventually will add interpretation done by the AI

 

For the time being, we will put just two things on the start page:

  • The “Title” component for short explanation of the app purpose
  • A “Button”, to open the records list page

We could show the list of records immediately on the start page, but making separate start page will allow us in the future to easily add new functions, without messing with the list of log records.

Put the text you want to display to app user at the start and the “Button”. Select the button and change its label to something like “Show records”. Open the logic canvas and put “Open page” flow function on it. Connect output of the “Component tap” with the input of the “Open page”. Select the “Open page” flow function and in the right-hand part of the screen, in “PROPRTIES” tab, select the “List of records” page to open (assuming you named so your page which will show the list of records).

Press “Save” in the top-right corner of the screen.

 

Task 3: Displaying the records.

The logic will work like this:

  1. Show the “Spinner”
  2. Get the records from the Auditlog service and put it in the data variable
  3. Hide the “Spinner”
  4. Show the records

 

Select the “List of records” page (or whatever you named your log list page).

Step 1:  The “Spinner”

First put the “Spinner” on the empty page, to make waiting for logs to appear a bit more pleasant.

We will need a variable to control visibility of the “Spinner”. As this variable matters only on this page, we will make it a “Page variable”.

  • Having the “List of records” page open, click the “Variables” tab at the very top of the screen.
  • Click “PAGE VARIABLES” on the left-hand side
  • Click “ADD PAGE VARIABLE” icon at the center of the screen
  • Select “From scratch”
  • Name the variable “PgVarSpinnerVisibility”
  • Change the “Variable value type” to “True/false”
  • Ensure that the “Initial value” is set to “False”
  • Save

Come back to the “User Interface” Tab at the top of the screen and select the “Spinner” you placed on the UI canvas and:

  • Change size to “large”
  • Open “ADVANCED PROPERTIES”
  • Click the square icon just below the “Visible” icon – dialog opens
  • Select “Data and Variables”
  • Select “Page variable”
  • Select the “PgVarSpinnerVisibility” variable you defined a minute ago
  • Save in the dialog
  • Switch to the “LAYOUT” tab
  • Open “POSITION” and select the icon to align it horizontally to the middle
  • Save in the top-right corner of screen

 

Step 2: The data to display

Then we need to define a data variable, based on the “records” entity we have in the integration. To do so, still having the “List of records” page open:

  • click on the “Variables” tab at the top of the screen
  • click “DATA VARIABLES” on the left side of the screen
  • click “ADD DATA VARIABLE” next to the plus in the circle sign
  • select “records”
  • change the default variable name in the “Data variable name” field of the right-side properties section to something meaningful, like “DataVarListOfRecords”
  • ensure that the “Data variable type” is set to “Collection of data records”
  • having selected the “DataVarListOfRecords”, open the “Logic canvas”
  • cut the link between “Page mounted” event and the “Get record collection” flow function
  • Insert here the “Set page variable” flow function – connect its input to the exit of the “Page mounted” event and connect its exit to the input of the “Get record collection” flow function.
  • Select the “Set page variable” flow function
  • Select the “PgVarSpinnerVisibility” under the “Variable name” label
  • Select “True” under the “Assigned value” label
  • Add second “Set page variable” flow function
  • Connect its input to the exit of the “Set data variable” output
  • Select the second “Set page variable” flow function
  • Select the “PgVarSpinnerVisibility” under the “Variable name” label
  • Select “False” under the “Assigned value” label
  • Save

The function flow should look like this:

 

 

 

Step 3: Define visual structure of the list of records.

You can use here any ready to use list, available in the “MARKETPLACE” section, but I prefer to shape the list using “Row” as this approach gives me the full control over what and how is displayed on the screen.

We will show here only three fields, but you can modify this structure any way you want.

  • Put the “Row” component on the UI canvas
  • Change layout of the “Row” to have three cells (do it in the right-hand section, “LAYOUT” tab)
  • Define width of each cell as 1

 

  • Put “Text” component in each cell of the row

In the future you can improve the look of this page by adding borders, backgrounds, headers etc, but now we are going just to display the list of records the simplest way.

Select the row. Note you must select entire row and not just e cell. The easiest way is to use the “TREE” view at bottom-right part of the screen.

 

 

With row selected, go to the “PROPERTIES” tab in the section above the tree view and click the square icon labeled “Repeat with”.

 

A dialog will open – select “Data and Variables”, then “Data variable” and then the data variable we defined just a few minutes ago (“DataVarListOfRecords”).

Click “Save” (in the dialog) and then again “Save” (top-right corner of screen).

We have “Text” component in each cell, so now we will connect each “Text” with proper data to display.

Select the first “Text” in the “Row” and in the right-hand “PROPERTIES” tab click the icon just below the “Content” label. Dialog opens – select “Data item in repeat”.

 

Ten select “current”. Find and select “time” and press “Save”.

Select the second “Text” in the “Row” and configure it the same way as the first one, but this time select “category”.

Select the third “Text” in the “Row” and configure it the same way as the first one, but this time select “tenant”.

Finally, press the “Save” button in the top-right corner of the screen to save the application.

The last thing we will add on this page is a “Button” to come back to the start page:

  • Place a “Button” just below the “Row” on the UI canvas
  • Change label of the button to “Back”
  • Format the button as you like using the “STYLE” and “LAYOUT” tabs on the right-hand side of the screen
  • Click the “arrow up” icon at the very bottom of the screen, named “Add logic to LIST OF RECORDS”. The text “LIST OF RECORDS” is the name of this page, so if you named the page differently, you would see your name of the page instead of the “LIST OF RECORDS”
  • Find “Navigate back” flow function in the “CORE” tab of the “LOGIC CANVAS” and place it next to the “EVENT Component tap” block on the logic canvas
  • Connect exit of the “Component tap” with the input of the “Navigate back” flow function
  • Save

 

 

Step 4: adding full view of the selected record

Now we will take care of the “Record details” page of our app. The Auditlog service does not allow for requesting just one record, based on its id (at the date of writing), so we will do all the data preparation work on the “List of records” page we already have running and then write the record data to the Application Variable to make it available to the “Record details” page, which in turn will be responsible for displaying the already prepared data.

The procedure will look like this:

  1. User clicks on the desired record in the displayed list
  2. App logic of the “List of records” page searches for the desired record in the data variable “DataVarListOfRecords”
  3. App logic of the “List of records” page writes the data of the record it found to the Application Variable
  4. App logic of the “List of records” page opens the “Record details” page
  5. The “Record details” page shows record details

Create the Application Variables

We will need two application variables.

  1. Go to the “Variables” tab
  2. Select “APP VARIABLES”
  3. Select “ADD APP VARIABLE”
  4. Select “From existing schema”
  5. Select “Entity”
  6. Select the entity we created in chapter “B. Application building.” paragraph “Preparation of the data structure for the list of records to repeat with”. We named this entity “records”
  7. Change name of the app variable to “AppVarSingleRecord”
  8. Select “ADD APP VARIABLE”
  9. Select “From scratch”
  10. Change name of the app variable to “AppVarMessageText”
  11. Make sure the “Variable value type” is “Text”
  12. Save

 

Activate the row, so clicking on any record activates the process of displaying its content

  1. Open the “User Interface” tab at the top of the screen
  2. Open the “List of records” page
  3. Select the “Row” – ensure you selected the row and not a single cell nor single text. Use the “TREE” view in the bottom-right corner of the screen for precise selection
  4. With “Row” selected, open the “LOGIC CANVAS”
  5. Drag to the logic canvas two “Set app variable” and one “Open page” flow functions.
  6. Connect all the flow function in one flow: “Component tap” -> “Set app variable” -> “Set app variable” -> “Open page”.
  7. First “Set app variable”:
    • “Variable name”: select “AppVarSingleRecord”
    • “Assigne value”:
      • click the square icon – dialog will open
      • select “Formula"
      • click on the formula line
      • delete the current formula
      • type “find_by” – two suggestions will show – double click the “FIND_BY_KEY”
      • highlight the “list” in the formula
      • select the “Data variables” on the left
      • double click the “DataVarListOfRecords”
      • highlight the “key” in the formula
      • type here “message_uuid” – this time type it WITH the quotation marks
      • highlight the “value” in the formula
      • select the “Currently repeated data item” on the left
      • double click the “repeated.current.message_uuid”
        The final formula should look like this:
        FIND_BY_KEY(data.DataVarListOfRecords, "message_uuid", repeated.current.message_uuid)
        if you name everything exactly like in my example, you can simply copy this formula and paste it in the formula field.
      • Save
  8. Second “Set app variable”:
    We want to show the “message” written in the log record, but its format makes it hard to read. We will make small but meaningful changes in the message format and this is the purpose of this flow function.
    1. “Variable name”: select “AppVarMessageText”
    2. “Assigne value”:
      • click the square icon – dialog will open
      • select “Formula”
      • click on the formula line
      • delete the current formula
      • put
        REPLACE_ALL(REPLACE_ALL(LEFT_STRIP(RIGHT_STRIP(appVars.AppVarSingleRecord.message, 1), 1),",","\n"),"\\","")
        as the formula – it removes the opening and closing brackets, relaces comas with new lines and removes backslashes
      • Save
  9. “Open page”: select “Record details” page to open
  10. Save

 

Build the UI of the “Record details” page

We already have the “Record details” page, but we need to put all the fields on it and connect them to the correct data sources. If we were to show just data entity, defined in the “Integrations” tab, we could use the AI for this task (assuming AI is enabled in your SAP Build environment). But we will not show the data entity – instead we will show content of the two application variables: “AppVarSingleRecord” and “AppVarMessageText”. So we need to design the page layout manually.

  1. Get familiar with structure of the AppVarSingleRecord application variable – note the data fields
  2. Open the “Record details” page
  3. Put a “Text” component on the UI canvas for each field of the variable
  4. For each “Text” component EXCEPT the one for “message” field do the following:
    1. select the “Text” component
    2. press the square icon just below the “Content” label in the “PROPERTIES” panel on the right-hand side – a dialog will open
    3. select “Data and variables”
    4. select “App variable”
    5. select “AppVarSingleRecord”
    6. select the data field you want to display using this “Text” component
    7. Save
  5. Select the “Text” component in which you want to display the message
    1. press the square icon just below the “Content” label in the “PROPERTIES” panel on the right-hand side – a dialog will open
    2. select “Data and variables”
    3. select “App variable”
    4. select “AppVarMessageText”
    5. Save
  6. Put a “Button” component at the end of the page and select it
  7. Open the logic canvas and drag here the “Navigate back” flow function and connect it to the “Component tap” event
  8. Save the application

Now you can use the “Preview” option in the top-right corner of the screen to test your application.

If the application works, now you can spend some time beautifying the application by:

  • Adding header row above the list of records in the “List of records” page
  • Adding additional, static texts as labels for dynamic text fields – here you can use rows for structured view
  • Adding containers and placing fields in the containers – to add visual structure to the pages
  • Manage borders, paddings and margins of the components
  • Manage color scheme

Finally, when you are happy with your app, go to the “Publish section, create build configuration, build the application and deploy.

 

Adding the date filters

As the application already works, we can see, that sometimes there is a lot of records to display. The Auditlog service’s API is limited: it can (as per date of writing) send back up to 500 records. You will find that quite often you would like the ability to define date range of log records to display.

Variables to store dates

We need to create in total four application variables to store the selected dates and to process them the way we need. Let’s create them right now:

Go to Variables -> APPLICATION VARIABLES and define the following variables:

  1. “DateFrom”
    • Variable value type: Date/time text (ISO8601)
  2. “DateTo”
    • Variable value type: Date/time text (ISO8601)
  3.  “DateFromTxt”
    • Variable value type: Text
    • Initial value: 0000-00-00T00:00:00
  4.  “DateToTxt”
    • Variable value type: Text
    • Initial value: 0000-00-00T00:00:00

 

UI modification

For simplicity, we will modify the “Home page” – our start page. We will add there two components: one for start date and the other one for end date. We will use ready to use “Date field”:

  1. Open the “Home page”
  2. Press “MARKETPLACE” in the UI components panel
  3. Search for “Date field” – at least three options will appear
  4. Select the option named just “Date field”
  5. Click “Install”
  6. Exit the “MARKETPLACE”
  7. Select “INSTALLED” in the UI components panel
  8. Find just installed “Date field” and drag it twice to the UI canvas – we need two of them
  9. Place both just above the already existing “Button”
  10. Select the topmost “Date field”
  11. Choose the “DateFrom” application variable in the “Selected value” property
  12. Type “Start date:” in the “Label” field
  13. Switch to the “LAYOUT” tab
  14. Expand the “WIDTH AND HEIGHT” section and select “Fit content”
  15. Scroll down to “POSITION” and select the icon to justify horizontally to the middle
  16. Scroll down to the “Z-index” and set it to “101”
  17. Select the lower “Date field”
  18. Choose the “DateTo” application variable in the “Selected value” property
  19. Type “End date:” in the “Label” field
  20. Switch to the “LAYOUT” tab
  21. Expand the “WIDTH AND HEIGHT” section and select “Fit content”
  22. Scroll down to “POSITION” and select the icon to justify horizontally to the middle
  23. Scroll down to the “Z-index” and set it to “100”

Now we will set the default values for both fields. Let’s assume that we want to see the current day’s log records by default.

  1. Click somewhere in the empty space of the “Home page” UI canvas
  2. Open the logic canvas
  3. Find “IF condition” flow function in the “CORE” section of the logic components and drag two instances to the logic canvas
  4. Find “Set app variable” and again drag two instances
  5. Connect inputs of both “IF condition” flow functions to the “Page mounted” event
  6. Connect exit of first “IF condition” flow function to the input of the first “Set app variable” flow function
  7. Connect exit of the second “IF condition” flow function to the input of the second “Set app variable” flow function
  8. Select first “IF condition” flow function
  9. Select “Formula” in the “Condition” field
  10. Put
    appVars.DateFromTxt=="0000-00-00T00:00:00"
    in the formula field
  11. Select second “IF condition” flow function
  12. Select “Formula” in the “Condition” field
  13. Put
    appVars.DateToTxt=="0000-00-00T00:00:00"
    in the formula field
  14. Select first “Set app variable” flow function
  15. Set “Variable name” to the application variable “DateFrom”
  16. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field and put
    NOW()
    in the formula field
  17. Select second “Set app variable” flow function
  18. Set “Variable name” to the application variable “DateTo”
  19. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field and put
    NOW()
    in the formula field – yes, we need the same value here
  20. Save the application

 

Data entity modification

We need to modify the data entity we defined in the “Integrations” tab, so let’s go there.

  1. Open the “Integrations” tab
  2. Select the “records” entity
  3. Scroll down to the very end of entity definition
  4. Find “Additional inputs”
  5. Add two additional inputs:
  6. “date_from” of type “Text”
  7. “date_to” of type “Text”

     



  8. Scroll up to the “Relative path and query” field
  9. Click it and replace the formula with:
    "/auditlog/v2/auditlogrecords?time_from="+query.additionalInputs.date_from+"&time_to="+query.additionalInputs.date_to
    this way we simply add two parameters to the REST API call and we do it the way that both parameters are set dynamically at the call based on the additional inputs we defined at the very bottom of the entity definition

     



  10. Note that now we see both additional inputs in the “Test” section of the “records” entity. If you want to test the entity now, you have to provide both inputs in the form: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS. For example 2025-06-13T00:00:00 for “date_from” and 2025-06-13T23:59:59 for “date_to”.

     



  11. Save the application
  12. Go to the “User interface” tab and open the “List of records” page
  13. Go to the “Variables” tab and select the “DATA VARIABLES” section
  14. Select the “DataVarListOfRecords” – now you see the two additional inputs
  15. Connect the “date_from” input to the “DateFromTxt” application variable
  16. Connect the “date_to” input to the “DateToTxt” application variable



17. Save the application

“Home page” button function modification

The Auditlog service API expects date/time to be sent in exact format and does not tolerate any differences, so we must transform the Date/time value we receive from the “Date field” components to exactly the format expected by the API.

  1. Open the “User Interface” tab
  2. Open the “Home page”
  3. Select the button
  4. Open the logic canvas
  5. Cut the connection between the “Component tap” event and the “Open page” flow function
  6. Drag two instances of the “Set app variable” function flow to the logic canvas
  7. Connect everything in single flow, with “Open page” flow function at the very end of the flow
  8. Select first “Set app variable” function flow
  9. Select “DateFromTxt” in the “Variable Name”
  10. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field
  11. Put
    SUBSTRING(appVars.DateFrom, 0, 11)+"00:00:00"
    in the formula field - we simply cut off everything what is after “T” in the “YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS” format. We need to do so as the format we receive from the “Date field” can vary and it contains milliseconds and can contain additional signs. Then we add the fixed time. In the future we could potentially make the time an additional, dynamic factor in the filters, though.
  12. Select second “Set app variable” function flow
  13. Select “DateToTxt” in the “Variable Name”
  14. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field
  15. Put
    SUBSTRING(appVars.DateTo, 0, 11)+"23:59:59"
    in the formula field
  16. Save the application
  17. Test the application in the “Preview”
  18. If everything works, build and deploy

 

 

Adding Artificial Intelligence for log message interpretation

Messages included in the logs can be difficult to read, understand and interpret. Adding AI might help a bit.

 

Setting up the AI in the SAP AI Core

Here I assume you already have access to the SAP AI Core and either have privileges needed to setup the AI deployment or you already have access to the AI deployment you can use in the application.

In short, when you start with the SAP AI Core:

  1. You have to create a resource group, where your resources, like configurations and deployments, will be stored.
  2.  You need to create a configuration of the LLM you will use.
  3. Create a deployment of your AI LLM, based on the configuration from point 2.

 

Creating the SAP BTP Destination

To proceed further we need the following information:

  1. SAP AI Launchpad: copy the name of the resource group you use – my resource group is named “default”
  2. SAP AI Launchpad: open the deployment you will use and copy its URL:

 

 

  1. SAP BTP Cockpit: you need the service key of the SAP AI Core service – more precisely you need authentication url, client id and client secret.

After gathering all the information, we need to define the destination in the SAP BTP subaccount, where SAP Build is deployed, pointing to the SAP AI Core’s AI deployment we will use.

Name: it is up to you. I use ChatGPT4o, so in my case the destination name is AI_Core_GPT4o

Type: HTTP

Proxy Type: Internet

URL: this is the url of the AI deployment, you copied this url in the SAP AI Launchpad

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID: copy from the SAP AI Core service’s service key

Client Secret: copy from the SAP AI Core service’s service key

Token service URL: this is the “url” value from the service key + /oauth/token – it should look like:

https://xxxxx.xxxxxxxx.xxxxxx.xxxxxxx.com/oauth/token

 

Token Service URL Type: Dedicated

 

 

And some additional properties:

The minimum:

  • BuildApps.Enabled = true
  • BuildApps.ApiType = rest
  • URL.headers.AI-Resource-Group = name of your resource group in the SAP AI Core – in my case it is “default”
    Note here that this is helpful if you use just one instance of the AI, located in one resource group. But if you use more AI instances and these instances are scattered among different groups, you can’t put the resource group name in the destination – instead you have to manage it in the application, in the REST API call.

 

And additional for the future use:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true
  • MobileEnabled = true

 

 

Accessing AI from SAP Build Apps

Let’s go now to the SAP Build Apps.

  1. Open the “Integrations” tab
  2. Click “ADD INTEGRATION”
  3. Find the “SAP Systems” tile and click “BTP DESTINATIONS”
  4. Find and select the destination we just defined
  5. Click the “INSTALL INTEGRATION”
    That’s all we need to do on the integration level – we don’t need any entity here as we will just call the BTP destination and directly process the reply.

 

Adding AI-related components to the application UI

Open the “Record Details” page. Drag the following on the UI canvas:

  • A button, to send request to the AI – name it “Send request to AI”
  • A spinner, to show that the process is running
  • A text field with the AI’s interpretation

I would also suggest adding text fields to display cost of the interpretation denominated in the SAP AI Core tokens:

  • Input tokens
  • Output tokens
  • Total tokens

Now we need to define some page variables. Most of them we will populate with data we get from the AI:

  • PgVarInputTokens - number
  • PgVarOutputTokens - number
  • PgVarTotalTokens - number
  • PgVarAiInterpretation - text

But one page variable will be used to store the template of the request:

  • PgVarRequestTemplate – text – set the “Initial value” to:
    The following text is audit log record. Provide short interpretation in less than 50 words.

Note: We use the simplest possible approach in this demo app, suitable for very small, probably single person development team. But in the real life, production version it would make sense to use SAP AI Core prompt templating function. Especially when there is a dedicated AI team in your organization – in such case the application development team should use templates prepared in advance by the AI team for all the AI requests.

 

Another variable will be used to build request to the AI:

  • In correct form
  • Containing correct request

 

  • PgVarMessageToAI – this variable is an object, containing list of objects with two properties:

{

    "PgVarMessageToAI": {

        "messages": [

            {

                "role": "text",

                "content": "text"

            }

        ]

    }

}

 

 

 

Add also one variable to control visibility of the spinner:

  • PgVarSpinnerVisible – true/false – set the “Initial value” to false

Now we need to connect page variables with “Text” components: go to “User Interface” tab, open the “Record Details” page and assign each “Text” component its variable in the “Content” field.

The button logic

Now let’s build the logic to send request and to process the response. Select the “Send request to AI” button and open its logic canvas. Place and connect flow functions as shown on the following image:

 

 

 

Flow functions configuration:

  1. Set page variable PgVarSpinnerVisible to true
  2. Set page variable PgVarMessageToAI, field messages, to list of values:
    1. Role set to user
    2. Content set to formula and the formula to: pageVars. PgVarRequestTemplate +" "+appVars.MessageText
  3. HTTP destination request:
    1. Destination: select the destination pointing to your AI deployment
    2. HTTP method: set to POST
    3. Request body type set to json
    4. Request body set to PgVarMessageToAi
    5. OPTIONAL INPUTS Path: set to
      /chat/completions?api-version=2024-10-21
      if you use ChatGPT4o like me. If you use different LLM, you have to use different path, suitable for your type and version of the LLM.
  4. Sep page variable PgVarSpinnerVisible to false
  5. Set page variable PgVarAiInterpretation to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.choices[0].message.content
    - this will glow in red and there will be a message that it is incorrect, but it will work anyway.
  6. Set page variable PgVarInputTokens to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.usage.prompt_tokens
    – again, ignore the red color and error message
  7. Set page variable PgVarOutputTokens to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.usage.completion_tokens
    – again ignore the message
  8. Set page variable PgVarTotalTokens to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.usage.total_tokens
    – the same story as above
  9. Alert: select formula for Dialog title and put
    "Failure status code: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].failureStatusCode+" | Failure status text: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].failureStatusText
    in the formula
  10. Alert: select formula for Dialog title and put
    "Error code: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].error.code+" | Error message: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].error.message
    in the formula

Save the application and test it in the preview – you should see interpretation by AI after a few seconds from pressing the “Send request to AI” button.

Build, deploy and enjoy! The demo application is ready. Now you can modify it up to your liking – adding features, beautifying the UI.

Please let me know if you would like to get the above project as .tar file, ready to upload to your SAP Build Apps environment.

Host, serve, and manage frontend applications to extend SAP business solutions.

Application Frontend service lets you host and serve frontend applications. It serves as a single entry point for hosting web-based UI applications to extend SAP's business solutions. The service provides tools for deploying and managing applications, serving static resources, routing backend calls to defined targets, and observability tools.

entry.title: Gamechanger Alert: Meet SAP Joule Studio for Real-World Impact
entry.content:
As someone who's still fairly new to SAP and learning about all it has to offer, I recently came across SAP Joule Studio—a tool that honestly surprised me. It’s part of SAP’s growing focus on AI, but instead of being just a tech buzzword, it’s something practical. Something helpful. Something that actually makes life easier.

So I thought I’d share what I’ve learned so far, for anyone else who’s curious like me.

 

What is SAP Joule Studio?

SAP Joule Studio is a low-code/no-code platform that lets you create AI-powered agents—little digital helpers that live inside your SAP system and support everyday tasks. These agents can:

  • Answer questions using real SAP data
  • Send reminders or alerts
  • Trigger workflows based on events
  • Help users navigate complex processes

The best part? You don’t need to be a developer to build one.

All you need is a good understanding of a business problem, and Joule Studio helps you turn that into a solution using easy visual tools.

 

Why This Is a Game-Changer (With Real Use Cases)

What really got me excited was seeing how real-world teams can use this tool to solve day-to-day challenges. Here are a few examples that really stood out to me:

✅HR & Employee Self-Service

  • Use Case: An AI agent that answers common HR questions like “How many vacation days do I have left?”, “What’s the process to update my bank details?”, or “When does my probation end?”
  • Impact: Reduces emails to HR, gives instant answers, and improves employee satisfaction.

✅Onboarding Assistant

  • Use Case: An AI agent that guides a new joiner through their first week—showing them how to complete paperwork, introducing them to teammates, and sending daily checklists.
  • Impact: Makes onboarding smoother, especially for remote hires or global teams.

✅Procurement Alerts

  • Use Case: A smart assistant that watches for delays from key suppliers and notifies procurement managers if a PO is stuck or overdue.
  • Impact: Keeps procurement responsive and improves relationships with vendors.

✅Project Management Summary

  • Use Case: A daily AI briefing that tells project leads about overdue tasks, timesheet gaps, or resource bottlenecks.
  • Impact: Saves hours of manual tracking and keeps teams aligned.

✅Compliance Checker

  • Use Case: A bot that checks which employees haven't completed their mandatory training or signed policy documents, and sends them a reminder.
  • Impact: Helps HR stay compliant without manual follow-ups.

✅IT Helpdesk Agent

  • Use Case: An agent that answers questions like “How do I reset my SAP password?” or “Where do I raise a ticket?”
  • Impact: Cuts down ticket volume for IT support and empowers users.

These aren’t just theoretical—they’re real issues we see in companies every day. And Joule Studio gives you a way to solve them quickly, without coding or waiting on IT.

 

Why Clients Will Love It Too

For clients, Joule Studio brings:

  • Self-service power to their SAP users
  • Less dependency on IT for small tasks
  • Smarter workflows with reminders, alerts, and guidance
  • Faster onboarding and training for new team members
  • Consistency across geographies and business units

AI becomes something helpful, not something scary or complex. It empowers users instead of overwhelming them.

 

Where You Can See It in Action

If you're like me and prefer learning visually, I highly recommend this official demo:

 SAP Joule Studio – AI for Everyone (YouTube)

You can also explore SAP’s official product page for more examples and how-to guides:
 SAP Joule Studio – Official Page

These are great starting points with visuals and real examples.

 

Getting Started with Joule Studio

If you’re ready to try it:

  1. Make sure your system is running on SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform).
  2. Go into SAP Build and access Joule Studio.
  3. Start by creating a small AI agent for a common task.
  4. Train it using real process examples and test in Preview mode.
  5. Roll it out with the right user permissions.

 

 

 

Remember—you don’t need to be technical. You just need to understand your business and what people are struggling with. Joule Studio helps you close that gap.

 

Final Thoughts (From One Learner to Another)

I’m still exploring SAP, still learning, and still asking questions. But tools like Joule Studio give me hope, not just for where tech is going, but for how we can make it work for people.

This isn’t about replacing humans—it’s about supporting them with small, smart helpers that remove friction and free up time.

If you're also exploring SAP tools and wondering where to start with AI, this might just be the right place. Try building a simple use case and see what it unlocks for your team.

And if you’ve tried it, I’d really love to hear what you’ve built. Let’s share and learn together, because the best ideas often come from the people closest to the problem.

entry.title: Send OData Batch Requests in SAP Build Apps (JSON)
entry.content:
Many people have asked about sending OData batch requests via SAP Build Apps. It can be done, if your API accepts JSON-formatted payloads for batch requests.

Just use the HTTP Destination Request flow function.

Then set the following:

  • Destination: Create an integration with your destination that points to your API (no need to specify any entities).
  • Method: POST
  • Body Type: JSON
  • Request Body: Just define a page variable with the JSON schema you need, and set the values with a Set Page Variable flow function. More on this below.
  • Path: /$batch
  • Headers: Content-Type = application/json

Request Body

The request body would be something like this (here we are create new records):

{
    "requests": [
        {
            "id": "1",
            "method": "POST",
            "url": "/Orders",
            "headers": {
                "content-type": "application/json; odata.metadata=minimal; odata.streaming=true",
                "odata-version": "4.0"
            },
            "body": {
                "customer": "JSON1",
                "date": "2021-06-30T00:00:00Z",
                "status": "Initiated",
                "total": 99,
                "currency_code": "USD"
            }
        },
        {
            "id": "2",
            "method": "POST",
            "url": "/Orders",
            "headers": {
                "content-type": "application/json; odata.metadata=minimal; odata.streaming=true",
                "odata-version": "4.0"
            },
            "body": {
                "customer": "JSON2",
                "date": "2021-06-30T00:00:00Z",
                "status": "Initiated",
                "total": 100,
                "currency_code": "USD"
            }
        }
    ]
}

For my test, I already had the JSON above so I just put it in a JavaScript component, parsed it, and output it.

But you could create a page variable, and in your app populate the variable with your data. Then you could use this page variable for the request body.

Unfortunately, I could not find a way to use the more traditional multipart/mixed payload format from SAP Build Apps. If you can find a way, let us know.

entry.title: Simple End to End Application development using SAP Build App
entry.content:
Simple End to End Application development using SAP Build App

Developing extension apps is a very common requirement among clients. Using Fiori application as an extension to SAP BTP was always an option but we can use SAP’s no code/ low code to develop a basic UI application which will connected to SAP SuccessFactors instance.

entry.title: SAP Build Apps: Getting data with “Get Record Collection” or maybe “HTTP Destination Request”?
entry.content:
“Get Record Collection”

The most common (and comfortable) way to get data from backend is to use “Get Record Collection” flow function. All we need to do is to install an integration with SAP system via its REST API using SAP BTP Destination.

 

 

 

If we enable the “Autogenerate configuration” option during installation of the integration, we will get even definition of the data structure, ready to use as a template for data variables.

 

 

We can even easily add call parameters, which are to be added to the relative path as a query – all we need is to add additional inputs in the entity definition:

 

These additional inputs will be automatically added in the relative path and in the test section of the data entity. And we can use these additional inputs to send additional parameters with the API call:

 

 

And, as data variable uses in fact “Get Record Collection” flow function in the background, we also can do the same with “Get Record Collection” flow function:

 

 

When “Get Record Collection” is not enough

Sometimes we need some additional information, not only the data itself – we need access to the header of the backend response – something the “Get Record Collection” flow function can’t easily (if at all) provide. And this is the case with getting data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service I wrote about in the previous blog (SAP BTP Global Account audit logs using SAP BTP Auditlog service, SAP Build Apps and SAP Ai Core). The issue with the Auditlog service is hat it does not always send requested data in single run. If the response should contain more data, the Auditlog service will use “paging”. It will send first portion (page) only, and you will have to request next portion of the answer data, and next one, till all the data is received.

How do we know that our application should request next page of data? Auditlog service, when paging is used, adds appropriate information in the response header. If all the data is sent without paging, there is no additional information in the header. But if next page is ready for sending, the Auditlog service will add “paging” field in the response header. This “paging” field has the following structure:

Paging: “handle=<page id>”

The value of the “Paging” field looks like this:



As “Get Record Collection” flow function doesn’t give us access to the response header in any simple way, the better option to get data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service is to use the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function, which gives access to both: data and headers the easy way.

How to use this header field? The logic should go as follows:

  1. Empty the variable containing the data to be displayed
  2. Request data with the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function
  3. Add the body of the response to the variable containing the data to be displayed
  4. If the “paging” field exists in the response header: send next request for data to the Auditlog, but this time add value of the “paging” field to the request path as the last parameter and jump back to step 3
  5. If the “paging” field doesn’t exist in the response header: display the content of the variable containing data

The logic should look like this:

 

How to get access to the response header? Using a formula. We can use the “outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders” in the formula. As the header is a json, it is enough to know the names of fields in the header and then we can check if field exists in the header:

IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

This function returns “true” if the field id undefined, otherwise it returns “false”.

And then, if we know that the field exists, we can get its value simply by its name like this:

outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

in the “Set App Variable” or “Set Page Variable” flow function.

I use both functions in single formula in the “Set Page Variable” flow function:

IF(IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging), "no_paging", outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging)

If the “paging” field is not defined in the header, the formula sets “no_paging” as the variable value. But if the “paging” field is defined, the formula sets its value as the variable value.

entry.title: SAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方とポイント
entry.content:
SAP BTP Hackathon 2025が無事終了しました。ご参加いただいた皆様、ありがとうございました。毎年多くの方にご参加いただき、今年も大変盛り上がりました。
毎年参加チーム数や提出作品のレベルが上がっており、運営側としては嬉しい悲鳴でした。

 

その中で、今年はSAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方についてのご質問が多かったように思えましたので、使い方とポイントを解説したいと思います。

 

「Repeat with」機能とは？

「Repeat with」機能はUIデザイン上で同じコンポーネントを繰り返し使用するための機能です。例えば、リストやテーブルなど、同じ形式のデータを複数表示する場合に非常に便利です。
「同じコンポーネント」というのは、例えばテキストやImageなどのUI要素のことを指します。

これらのUI要素のRepreat withプロパティに「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」をバインドすることにより、そのオブジェクトに残像のようなエフェクトが付きます。

「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」とはSAP Build AppsのVariable上で以下のような定義の変数を指します。


変数定義としてはList型であり、その中のItemのタイプとしてObject型、そのオブジェクト型の中にTextや数値型などのプロパティを含んでいる構造です。これはJSONで記述すると以下のようなものになります。

[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Alice",
    "contact": {
      "email": "alice@example.com",
      "phone": "123-456-7890"
    }
  },
  {
    "id": 2,
    "name": "Bob",
    "contact": {
      "email": "bob@example.com",
      "phone": "098-765-4321"
    }
  }
]

実行時にRepeat withで繰り返し表示がされる回数は与えたリスト型の変数の要素数（長さ、Length）に依存します。例えば、5つの要素を持つリスト型の変数を指定すると、5回繰り返し表示されます。
 

使い方

上に挙げたJSONのデータを利用してみます。このJSONのデータ形式をSAP Build Apps上で表現すると下記のような変数になります。

JSONの値をこの変数に代入して、Repeat withで使用してみます。

Repeat withにSampleListをバインドします。このHeadLineアイテムのContent（表示内容）にnameのデータを表示したいと思います。HeadLineアイテムのContentのアイコンをクリックし


Data Items in repeatをクリックし、

Currentをクリックするとウインドウ下部に展開されます。

"current"は現在の行を意味し、その中のどれをContentにバインドするか？ということです。nameを選択します。
プレビュー実行してみます。

このように一つのHeadLineアイテムが勝手にリピートされ、バインドしたリスト型の変数の要素（行）を繰り返し、その現在行に応じたデータを表示してくれます。これがRepeat withの機能です。

更に実践

このRepeat withできる要素にはRowやContainer等複数のUI要素をまとめる機能を持ったコンポーネントも含まれます。
Rowコンポーネント中にはCellが含まれていて横に並ぶようになっています。このRowコンポーネントを縦に並べると表のようなものが出来上がりますね。Rowコンポーネントを4セル設定にして、各セルにTextコンポーネントを配置し、Rowコンポーネント自体にRepeat withで変数を設定して各セルにid,name,email,phoneのプロパティをバインドさせた例がこちらです。

Rowコンポーネントのスタイルを変更して枠線を追加すれば表になるなということがわかるかと思います。

ちなみに、ROWコンポーネントのCellに対してRepeat withで変数をバインドすると、


Listの要素数分横に並べるということも出来ます。

Listの要素数（行数）が多いので表示される行数を絞りたいという場合は変数操作が必要です。Repeat withでバインドする際にFormulaを使用して式の形でバインドすると良いでしょう。例えば

SELECT関数を使用するとリスト型変数から要素の範囲を絞ったものを抜き出すことが出来ます。

例1：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index <10)
→ リストの先頭10件　（リストは0から開始します。）
例2：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index >= 10 && index < 20)
→リストの11件目から20件目まで

応用すればページ表示のようなことも出来ますね。

画面の表示される範囲を制御したいという場合はRepeat withするコンポーネントをScroll Viewコンポーネントの中に配置すると良いでしょう。

そうするとScroll View側のスタイルの設定で、Scroll View内で表示されることになります。

Repeat withは必要な回数分UIコンポーネントを繰り返し表示できる便利な機能です。是非使いこなしてください。

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Unfortunately, the Processes flow functions to trigger processes from SAP Build Apps (for now) do not work for shared environments. And since the public environment is deprecated, that means they essentially no longer work at all.  Hopefully this will be modified soon.

In the meantime, here's how to work around that issue.

The Issue

I am not sure but I assume the issue is that when you make an API call to trigger a process in a shared environment, you must send the environment id as a query parameter.

/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=salesgroup

But the flow functions do not have an input for the environment, so they automatically try to trigger a process in the public (default) environment.

By the way, the identifier for an environment can be found when you open the environment in the Control Tower.

The Workaround

The good news is SAP Build Apps recently added a new flow function called HTTP Destination Request that lets us create a customized HTTP request but using a destination. That is we get the control we get from the HTTP Request flow function but with the ability to connect through a destination.

As a prerequisite you need to have a destination called sap_process_automation_service_user_access to the SAP Build Process Automation service, the same as if you wanted to use the Processes flow functions. This is described in the Processes documentation.

You will need to add the destination properties so that it appears in your SAP Build Apps project:

BuildApps.Enabled = true
BuildApps.ApiType = rest

To add the destination to your project:

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.                                                         
  3.  Click BTP Destinations.
  4. Select the destination.
  5. Click Install Integration.                      

If you go back to the Integrations tab main screen, you'll see the destination. That's all you need to do to add the destination to the project and make it available to your HTTP Destination Request flow function.

To trigger a process deployed to a shared environment, do the following:

  1. Add a button.
  2. In the logic canvas for the button, add an HTTP Destination Request, along with any Alert flow functions to show the result or error
  3. Select the HTTP Destination Request, and set the following in the Properties tab.
    Destinationsap_process_automation_service_user_access
    HTTP MethodPOST
    Request Body Typejson
    Request BodyThis depends on the proper request body for your process. More on this below.
    Path
    /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=<environment ID>

    Replace the placeholder with the identifier for your environment.

    Response Typetext

       

The flow function has 3 outputs.

  • The first if the call is successful and returns 2XX status code.
  • The second if the call is successfully transmitted and a response is received but returns a 4XX or 5XX status code.
  • The third if the call is unsuccessful and no response is received.  

Request Body

The request body is determined by checking the trigger for the process.

  1. Go to the Control Tower.
  2. Click Environments.
  3. Click your environment.
  4. Click Triggers.
  5. Click View next to the trigger for your process.

You will now see the payload for the API for that trigger. This will be the request body.

Note that you cannot copy from the box with the payload. You will have to use the copy button to copy the entire payload. Note also you can see the URL for the API, including the environmentId parameter you must pass.

The Upshot

The method above is pretty straight-forward and has the advantage of teaching you what is happening behind the scenes and how the SAP Build Process Automation APIs work. But I'll admit you lose the ease of use of the flow functions, and also the ability to create variables from the input and output schema of your processes.

entry.title: Extend a Custom Business Object created with Key User Extensibility using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
This blog post covers how to setup an extension scenario from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and build Side-by-Side UI Extensions with the help of SAP Build Apps in the Business Technology Platform.

Business scenario:

A Manager wants to define business objects “Bonus Plan” for employees. A Bonus Plan is there to save employee specific rules for bonus entitlement.

Here, with Key User Extensibility, we create a custom Business Object with a data structure, logic for data initialization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition which should have standard API operations (GET, POST, DELETE). Expose the custom business object as web service for side-by-side UI extension using Low-code No-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will learn how quickly a new UI application can be developed with the no-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will also find out what is the process to setup, develop and deploy a productive extension application.

Note: The maintain Bonus app shown in this blog is for educational purpose only and not meant for productive usage. It is not ensured that the data used in this extension scenario is managed in accordance with applicable legal requirements for all countries and industries and in accordance with the business needs, such as data life cycle requirements.  

Prerequisites:

  1. Subscription to SAP Build Apps on SAP BTP Sub-Account
  2. Your user needs (a) business role(s) with business catalogs Extensibility - Custom Business Objects (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CBO), Extensibility - Custom Communication Scenarios (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CCS) and Communication Management (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_COM) (Need to have unrestricted access if you are creating a business role and adding these catalogs).

Why SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA Cloud?

entry.title: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
What is “clean core”?

Let’s dive a bit deeper to understand what exactly this means: An SAP S/4HANA Cloud solution has a clean core when it is up to date, documented, unmodified, consistent, efficient, and has custom extensions decoupled from SAP source code.

The clean core concept has multiple dimensions:

  • Business Processes: reduce complexity, because complex processes slow down upgrade cycles
  • Extensibility: decouple extensions from the standard
  • Data: control the data to the latest standards, with respect to volume, cleanliness, accuracy
  • Integration: keep your IT landscape reliable and flexible, using standard APIs and events
  • Operations: keep your operations effective and efficient

In this blog post, we will focus on the method for maintaining this clean core while adapting SAP solutions to meet specific business needs, which is called “clean core extensibility”. Flexibility will continue to benefit you in the future if extensions are built and utilized in adherence to clean core principles. For this, SAP provides the private cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Note: The clean core concept only applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, as the Public Cloud Edition cannot be customized in its source code, only extended. For the public cloud, SAP provides the public cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which also leverages the SAP BTP.

Now, back to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

What Is New: The Evolution Of The 3-Tier Model – Introducing The Clean Core Level Concept

SAP is evolving its extensibility guidelines by introducing the Clean Core Level Concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP S/4HANA, now including rules for classic ABAP. By evolving the previous 3-tier model, this new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles.

This allows for a more granular assessment of an extension's quality and upgrade stability, rather than a simple binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. The core recommendation remains a "BTP-first" strategy, aiming for the highest possible level, but the new model acknowledges the realities of complex, grown system landscapes and allows customers to  personalize their clean core journeys. The fundamental principles of Clean Core—decoupling extensions from the standard SAP code to ensure upgrade stability—remain essential.

How It Works: The Four Clean Core Levels Explained

According to the Clean Core Level Concept, each extension is evaluated using a standardized methodology that looks at how the extension is built, how well it is decoupled from the core, and how easily it can be upgraded or maintained. Here are the key details of the Clean Core Level Concept:

Overview of Clean Core Levels

The Clean Core Level Concept categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D), each representing varying degrees of compliance with Clean Core principles:

  1. Level A : Extend with SAP Build

    • Description: Extensions in this level are fully compliant with Clean Core principles and interact with SAP standard functionality through publicly released interfaces and extension points.
    • Characteristics:
      • Side-by-Side: Developed on SAP BTP, utilizing all options of the SAP Build portfolio including AI-powered pro-code and low-code tools.
      • On-Stack: Built within the SAP S/4HANA system using the ABAP Cloud development model with released APIs.
    • Benefits: Maximum upgrade stability and alignment with SAP's clean core vision.

  2. Level B : Leverage Classic APIs

    • Description: Extensions at this level can access "classic APIs" from SAP, in addition to meeting Level A criteria.
    • Characteristics:
      • These APIs are well-defined, documented, and generally upgrade-stable but do not come with formal stability contracts.
      • Classic technologies and frameworks can be used, which have a long-standing history of reliable use.
    • Benefits: Broader scope for process enhancements compared to Level A while maintaining a degree of upgrade stability.

  3. Level C : Access Internal Objects

    • Description: Extensions classified as Level C can access internal SAP objects that are not officially released or supported.
    • Characteristics:
      • These objects may lack documentation and long-term stability guarantees.
      • A changelog for SAP objects is provided to help customers assess upgrade risks proactively.
    • Benefits: Offers flexibility for legacy scenarios but poses notable risks regarding future upgrade stability.

  4. Level D : Not Recommended Extensions

    • Description: Extensions in this category use objects or techniques that SAP has explicitly marked as "not recommended."
    • Characteristics:
      • Includes modifications to SAP standard code, implicit enhancements, and direct write access to SAP tables.
      • Represents the highest risk and the most significant technical debt.
    • Consequences: These extensions threaten system stability and upgradeability and should be prioritized for immediate remediation.

Importance of the Level Concept

  • Granular Assessment: The level concept allows for a more nuanced evaluation of extensions compared to a binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. This granularity helps organizations understand the specific risks associated with their custom code.
  • Guidance for Development: By categorizing extensions into levels, developers can make informed decisions about which technologies and practices to adopt, aiming for the highest possible level of compliance.
  • Facilitating Modernization: The framework supports organizations in managing their existing codebases effectively, helping them prioritize remediation of the highest-risk extensions (Level D) while promoting the adoption of clean, upgrade-stable practices.

Conclusion

The Clean Core Level Concept is essential for organizations leveraging SAP S/4HANA, offering a clear framework to assess and categorize custom extensions. By distinguishing between Levels A, B, C, and D, it enables businesses to make informed development decisions, prioritize remediation of high-risk extensions, and ensure compliance with Clean Core principles. This structured approach not only helps manage technical debt but also simplifies upgrades and enhances overall system integrity, paving the way for sustained agility and innovation. Embracing this framework is key to maintaining a robust and future-ready ERP landscape.

Leverage SAP Build for creating extensions

The go-to place following SAP-recommended best practices to create extensions optimized for SAP software development is SAP Build. It includes

  • powerful low-code, pro-code (ABAP, Java, JavaScript), and generative AI capabilities
  • enhanced interoperability with SAP S/4HANA

to empower developers and business experts to create extensions for SAP software with greater efficiency. It allows you to accelerate ERP modernization, foster innovation, and automate processes – all within a single comprehensive suite of solutions.

 

Accelerate extension of SAP S/4HANA with AI capabilities enabled by Joule

New levels of Cloud ERP efficiency can be unlocked with the latest AI capabilities enabled by Joule in SAP Build. Joule is SAP’s AI copilot offering conversational interactions in the respective business context. Uniquely trained on SAP data and processes, it helps developers write code and design workflows for SAP S/4HANA across ABAP, Java, JavaScript, and low-code tools. As an integral part of SAP Build, Joule is the copilot for SAP development and makes developers more efficient with their development tasks for SAP S/4HANA.

Joule generates high-quality code and code explanations aligned with SAP’s programming models, thereby reducing development time for both new and experienced developers and accelerating migration to cloud ERP with a clean core.

AI capabilities enabled by Joule can also be used to extend ERP through low-code application development. Joule assists with process automation, expediting the creation of workflows for SAP S/4HANA and guiding workflow approvers with automated recommendations.

How to Get Started?

First and foremost, read our white paper on Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud . The last chapter of the document details the six-step path to a clean core and links to many useful resources to deep dive:

  1. Start with the clean core concept and definition
  2. Apply the concept and create your specific clean core strategy
  3. Analyze existing custom code (brownfield only)
  4. Adopt extension guidelines and methodologies
  5. Establish clean core governance and operations
  6. Build extensions

In addition, depending of the line of business you’re involved in, read our eBook presenting how to Extend SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build with use cases by LoB, including Finance, Supply chain, Sales and service, Operations and IT.

And regarding the use of SAP Build for extending your ERP, I recommend watching the replay of our SAP Build Live online event on Clean Core extensibility with SAP Build held on October 23, where our partner LeverX shared insights from a real customer use case.

For ABAP-based extensibility for clean core see the ABAP Extensibility Guide.

Finally, we have a learning journey for you:

Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud will present you how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP so that they can maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. It is for beginners, takes 2 hours and is free.

Now you're ready to begin your fruitful journey to achieve Clean Core!

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
A few months ago, we shared our excitement about the launch of the first-ever SAP BTP Hackathon in Africa in joined collaboration of AFSUG and SAP, highlighting the unique opportunity it offered for AFSUG members to bring their creativity and problem-solving skills to the forefront of the SAP community. Now, with the event behind us, it’s time to reflect on what unfolded and celebrate the teams and ideas that made this inaugural Hackathon truly special.

From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration

As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025’s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

And the Winner Is… PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform “Legal Ease”. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. “Legal Ease” enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: “Legal Ease” addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let’s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

Reflections and What’s Next

The Hackathon’s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

“It is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we’ve seen incredible progress and innovation.”

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: AI‑Powered Self‑Service Portal with SAP Build Apps and SAP Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Abstract

In this demo, we showcase an intelligent self‑service portal built with SAP Build Apps, seamlessly integrated with SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core. End users submit a service request by uploading an image . The image is analyzed in AI Core to detect key objects or issues; the findings are then merged into the case description so agents start with rich context. We also run sentiment analysis on the user’s text, helping auto‑prioritize and categorize the case. The result is an end‑to‑end, low‑code + AI workflow that reduces manual effort, improves accuracy, and accelerates resolution time.

Use Case: Broken Home Appliance Service Request

Scenario:
A customer’s washing machine stops working and makes unusual noise. Instead of calling customer support, they log into the self-service portal built on SAP Build Apps.

What you’ll build

A responsive self‑service portal where customers can:

  • Log in, fill a lightweight form, and upload a photo (e.g., broken product/utility issue).
  • See real‑time AI insights (objects detected; suspected issue) before submitting.
  • Submit a Service Request (Case) to Service Cloud V2, with AI context appended to the description and sentiment tag auto‑set.

Agents in Service Cloud V2 will see a richer ticket with:

  • Customer text + image URL/attachment.
  • AI object/issue summary and confidence scores.
  • Sentiment label (Positive/Neutral/Negative) for quick triage.

Solution Overview

The solution leverages three modern SAP technologies:

  • SAP Build Apps: Low-code environment for building web/mobile self-service portals.
  • SAP BTP Destination: Secure connection layer to backend SAP services.
  • SAP Service Cloud V2: Manages and tracks customer service cases.
  • SAP AI Core: Automates image analysis and sentiment analysis to enhance ticket information

The workflow (as visualized below) demonstrates how these layers interact:

  • End-to-End Ticket Automation: Instantly raise service requests by uploading an image.
  • AI-Powered Image Analysis: Automatic detection of objects or issues in uploaded images via SAP AI Core.
  • Auto-Enriched Ticket Descriptions: AI writes relevant context and details.
  • Sentiment Analysis: Analyzes customer descriptions for emotion and urgency for better case triaging.

Reference architecture

 

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have the following in place:

SAP BTP Account with access to:

  • SAP Build Apps service
  • SAP AI Core service
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 tenant

Service Keys and Destinations:

  • Properly configured SAP BTP Destination for Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core

AI Models Deployed:

  • Object Detection model ( in SAP AI Core)
  • Sentiment Analysis model
  • Basic understanding of SAP BTP, Destinations, and Service Cloud concepts

Step‑by‑step build guide

1.Prepare Your AI Services in SAP AI Core

  • Deploy or onboard your image recognition and sentiment analysis models to SAP AI Core.
  • Expose these models through RESTful endpoints.

2. Configure Destinations in SAP BTP Cockpit

Create destinations for:

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 API
  • SAP AI Core inference endpoints
  • Set appropriate authentication methods (OAuth2, Basic, etc.).

3.Build the Self-Service Portal with SAP Build Apps

  • Use SAP Build Apps’ drag-and-drop interface to design a user-friendly portal.
  • Add functionality for:
    • User authentication
    • Image upload
    • Input fields for additional ticket information
  • Configure data resources to connect to SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core via the BTP destinations.

Build the portal in SAP Build Apps

Step 1: Create an SAP Build Apps portal tailored to your requirements.

Step 2: Implement logic to process the uploaded image using SAP AI Core. Extract the description from the image and perform sentiment analysis on the extracted text. Based on the description and sentiment, automatically update the subject line and categorize the case accordingly.

Step 3: Invoke the Service Cloud V2 API to create a case along with the attachment.

Video

 

Summary

This approach shows how you can build a pure destination‑driven integration between Build Apps, AI Core, and Service Cloud V2. By leveraging SAP BTP Destinations, you eliminate the need for custom middleware, keep the architecture lightweight, and still enable AI‑powered case creation with images, sentiment, and prioritization.
